revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1618|music}}
The year '''1618 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
== Events == * Beginning of the [[Thirty Years' War]] (1618–1648), which will disrupt German musical establishments, and will affect the nature of the music composed by those who endured the widespread devastation, famine, and disease of this period. * The formula for making [[Zildjian]] [[cymbal]]s is discovered in [[Turkey]]. *[[Robert Ballard (lutenist)|Robert Ballard]] becomes lutenist and composer at the court of King [[Louis XIII of France]]. *[[Michael East (composer)|Michael East]] is choirmaster at Lichfield Cathedral.
== Publications == *Michael East – ''The Fourth Set Of Bookes ... to 4. 5. and 6. Parts: Apt for Viols and Voyces'' *[[Johann Hermann Schein]] – ''Opella nova'' (Little new works), volume 1, a collection of sacred concertos *[[René Descartes]] – ''Compendium Musicae'' *[[Michael Praetorius]] – ''De Organographia''
== Classical music == *[[Gregorio Allegri]] – Concerti, vol. 1
== Opera == *[[Claudio Monteverdi]] – ''Andromeda'' (lost)<ref>{{cite journal | last = Rosenthal | first = Albi | title = Monteverdi's 'Andromeda': A Lost Libretto Found|journal= Music & Letters|volume= 66|issue= 1|date= January 1985|pages=1–8 | jstor = 855431 | doi = 10.1093/ml/66.1.1}}</ref>
== Births == *''date unknown'' **[[Solomon Eccles]], composer (died 1683) **[[Pierre Robert (composer)|Pierre Robert]], composer (died 1699)
== Deaths == *[[December 10]] – [[Giulio Caccini]], Italian composer (born 1551) *[[December 12]] – [[Pedro de Cristo]], composer (born c.1550)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1618|Music]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

{{Infobox film | name = 17 Girls | image = 17 Girls poster.png | caption = Film poster | director = [[Delphine and Muriel Coulin|Delphine Coulin]]
[[Delphine and Muriel Coulin|Muriel Coulin]] | producer = Denis Freyd{{cite web|url=http://www.miami.com/03917-girls039-unrated-article|title='17 Girls' (Unrated)|last=Ogle|first=Connie|date=27 September 2012|work=[[Miami Herald]]|accessdate=4 October 2013}} | writer = Delphine Coulin
Muriel Coulin | starring = [[Louise Grinberg]]
[[Juliette Darche]]
[[Roxane Duran]]
[[Esther Garrel]]{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2012/09/21/movies/17-girls-directed-by-delphine-and-muriel-coulin.html|title=Follow the Leader, to Extremes: '17 Girls,' Directed by Delphine and Muriel Coulin|last=Holden|first=Stephen|date=20 September 2012|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=4 October 2013}}
[[Florence Thomassin]]
[[Noémie Lvovsky]] | music = | cinematography = Jean-Louis Vialard | editing = Guy Lecorne | distributor = Diaphana Films | released = {{Film date|df=y|2011|05|14|[[2011 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]]|2011|12|14|France}} | runtime = 86 minutes | country = France | language = French | budget = $3 million | gross = $716,542http://www.jpbox-office.com/fichfilm.php?id=12543 }} '''''17 Girls''''' ({{lang-fr|'''17 filles'''}}) is a 2011 French [[comedy-drama]] film about 17 teenage girls who make a pregnancy pact. The film was screened at the 2011 [[Montreal World Film Festival]]{{cite web|url=http://roverarts.com/2011/08/i-want-one-too/|title=I Want One, Too|last=Lake|first=Michael|date=30 August 2011|work=The Rover|accessdate=4 October 2013}} and the [[2011 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/17-girls-17-filles-cannes-188483|title=17 Girls (17 Filles): Cannes Review|last=Mintzer|first=Jordan|date=15 May 2011|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=4 October 2013}} ''17 Girls'' is based on the [[pregnancy pact|alleged pregnancy pact]] that took place at [[Gloucester High School (Massachusetts)|Gloucester High School]] in Massachusetts in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2012/09/07/_17_girls_the_pregnancy_pact_revisited_as_a_french_feminist_fantasy_.html|title=17 Girls: The pregnancy pact revisited as a French, feminist fantasy.|last=Hess|first=Amanda|date=7 September 2012|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=4 October 2013}} The 2010 American film ''[[The Pregnancy Pact]]'' is based on the same story. ==Plot== In Lorient, 17 teenage girls from the same high school make an unexpected decision, incomprehensible to the boys and adults. They decide to get pregnant at the same time. Camille (Louise Grinberg) lives alone with her mother who is overwhelmed by her work. She becomes pregnant after a condom problem with a sexual partner who is not her boyfriend. She is the first to discover a positive pregnancy test. She wants to keep her child, which will convince the others to become pregnant and they can all raise their children together. These girls do not want to comply with the traditional code of conduct and just want to "give the love they have to a baby." Emancipation, is the keyword of these girls who build a plan to no longer be reflections of their parents. "We will be only 16 years apart from our kids, this is ideal. We will be closer in age, no clash of generations!" They decide to educate their future children together in the form of a "hippie community." In the end, Camille loses her baby after a minor traffic accident. She and her mother leave town without telling anyone where they've gone. The other girls have their babies, but they do not form a "community." ==Cast== * [[Louise Grinberg]] : Camille * [[Esther Garrel]] : Flavie * [[Roxane Duran]] : Florence * [[Solène Rigot]] : Mathilde * Juliette Darche : Julia * Yara Pilartz : Clementine * [[Florence Thomassin]] : Camille's mother * [[Noémie Lvovsky]] : high school nurse * Carlo Brandt : the headmaster * Frédéric Noaille : Florian * Arthur Verret : Tom * Jocelyne Desverchère : Clementine's mother * [[Serge Moati]] : TV journalist ==Reception== [[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere magazine]] likened ''17 Girls'' to ''[[The Virgin Suicides (film)|The Virgin Suicides]]'' by [[Sofia Coppola]] saying "same languid pop, same delicately grainy picture, same kind of heterogeneous female cast, same absence of boys, reduced to the roles of stooges".{{Cite web |url=http://www.premiere.fr/film/17-Filles-2399924/%28affichage%29/press |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-01-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924130112/http://www.premiere.fr/film/17-Filles-2399924/%28affichage%29/press |archive-date=2015-09-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Awards and nominations== *Nominated for the [[Camera d'Or]] at the [[2011 Cannes Film Festival]] *Won the [[Deauville American Film Festival#Prix Michel d'Ornano|Michel d'Ornano Award]] at the [[Deauville American Film Festival]] *Nominated for the 2012 [[César Award for Best First Feature Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|1860152}} {{Delphine and Muriel Coulin}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]] [[Category:Teenage pregnancy in film]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Films directed by Delphine and Muriel Coulin]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Use British English|date=February 2018}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = 84, Charing Cross Road | image = 84 charing cross first.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = New York | language = | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = | set_in = | publisher = Grossman Publishers | publisher2 = | pub_date = 1970 | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = 9780670290734 | isbn_note = | oclc = 99564 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} '''''84, Charing Cross Road''''' is a 1970 book by [[Helene Hanff]], later made into a stage play, television play, and [[84 Charing Cross Road (film)|film]], about the twenty-year correspondence between the author and [[Frank Doel]], chief buyer of [[Marks & Co]] antiquarian booksellers, located at the [[eponymous]] address in [[London]], England.
==Background== Hanff was in search of obscure classics and British literature titles that she had been unable to find in [[New York City]] when she noticed an ad in the ''[[Saturday Review (US magazine)|Saturday Review of Literature]]''. She first contacted the shop in 1949 and it fell to Doel to fulfil her requests. In time, a long-distance friendship developed between the two and between Hanff and other staff members, as well, with an exchange of [[Christmas]] packages, birthday gifts and food parcels to help with the post-[[World War II]] [[Rationing in the United Kingdom#After World War II|food shortages in Britain]]. Their letters included discussions about topics as diverse as the sermons of [[John Donne]], how to make [[Yorkshire Pudding]], the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]] and the [[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II|coronation of Elizabeth II]]. Hanff postponed visiting her English friends until too late; Doel died in December 1968 from [[peritonitis]] from a burst [[Vermiform appendix|appendix]], and the bookshop eventually closed in December 1970. Hanff did finally visit [[Charing Cross Road]] and the empty shop in the summer of 1971, a trip recorded in her 1973 book ''The Duchess of Bloomsbury Street''.
==The shop's site today== The five-story building where Marks & Co. was located during the events of the book still exists {{nowrap|({{coord|51.51365|-0.12916|format=dms|type:landmark_region:GB}})}}. A circular brass plaque on a [[pilaster]] on the street frontage acknowledges the story and marks the site. The premises were occupied by a music and [[Compact disc|CD]] shop in the early 1990s, and later other retail outlets. In 2009 they housed a Med Kitchen restaurant; and now form part of a [[McDonald's]] restaurant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.84charingcrossroad.co.uk/hist2.html |title=A Brief History – Page 2|work=84charingcrossroad.co.uk|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref>
==Bibliography== Partial list of the books that Helene Hanff ordered from Marks & Co. and mentioned in ''84 Charing Cross Road'' (alphabetical order):
* [[Jane Austen|Austen, Jane]]. ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'', (1813) * Arkwright, Francis trans. ''Memoirs of the [[Louis de Rouvroy, duc de Saint-Simon|Duc de Saint-Simon]]'' * [[Hilaire Belloc|Belloc, Hillaire]]. ''Essays''. * [[Catullus]] – [[Loeb Classics]] * [[Geoffrey Chaucer|Chaucer, Geoffrey]] ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' translated by Hill, published by Longmans 1934) * [[E. M. Delafield|Delafield, E.M.]], ''Diary of a Provincial Lady'' * [[Austin Dobson|Dobson, Austen ed.]]. ''[[Roger de Coverley|The Sir Roger De Coverley Papers]]'' * [[John Donne|Donne, John]] ''Sermons'' * Elizabethan Poetry * [[Kenneth Grahame|Grahame, Kenneth]], ''[[The Wind in the Willows]]'' * Greek New Testament * [[Jean Grolier de Servières|Grolier]] Bible * [[William Hazlitt|Hazlitt, William]]. ''Selected Essays Of William Hazlitt 1778 To 1830'', Nonesuch Press edition. * [[Horace]] – [[Loeb Classics]] * [[James Henry Leigh Hunt|Hunt, Leigh]]. ''Essays''. * [[Samuel Johnson|Johnson, Samuel]], ''On Shakespeare'', 1908, Intro by Walter Raleigh * [[Ben Jonson|Jonson, Ben]]. ''Timber'' * [[Charles Lamb (writer)|Lamb, Charles]]. ''[[Essays of Elia]]'', (1823). * [[Walter Savage Landor|Landor, Walter Savage]]. Vol II of ''The Works and Life of Walter Savage Landor'' (1876) – ''[[Imaginary Conversations]]'' * Latin Anglican New Testament * [[Latin Vulgate Bible]] / Latin Vulgate New Testament * Latin Vulgate Dictionary * Leonard, R. M. ed. The Book-Lover's Anthology, (1911). * [[John Henry Newman|Newman, John Henry]]. ''Discourses on the Scope and Nature of University Education. Addressed to the Catholics of Dublin''- "'Idea of a University" (1852 and 1858) * [[Samuel Pepys|Pepys, Samuel]]. ''Pepys Diary'' – 4 Volume Braybrook ed. (1926, revised ed) * [[Plato]]'s ''Four Socratic Dialogues'', 1903 * [[Arthur Quiller-Couch|Quiller-Couch, Arthur]], ''The Oxford Book Of English Verse'' * [[Arthur Quiller-Couch|Quiller-Couch, Arthur]], ''The Pilgrim's Way'' * [[Arthur Quiller-Couch|Quiller-Couch, Arthur]], ''Oxford Book of English Prose'' * [[Sappho]] – [[Loeb Classics]] * St. John, Christopher Ed. ''[[Ellen Terry]] and [[George Bernard Shaw|Bernard Shaw]] : A Correspondence / The Shaw – Terry Letters : A Romantic Correspondence'' * [[Laurence Sterne|Sterne, Laurence]], ''[[The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman]]'', (1759) * [[Robert Louis Stevenson|Stevenson, Robert Louis]]. ''Virginibus Puerisque'' * [[Alexis de Tocqueville|de Tocqueville, Alexis]] ''Journey to America'' (1831–1832) * [[Thomas Wyatt (poet)|Wyatt, Thomas]]. ''Poems of Thomas Wyatt'' * [[Izaak Walton|Walton, Izaak]]. ''The Compleat Angler'' . J Major's (2nd ed., 1824). * [[Izaak Walton|Walton, Izaak]]. ''The Lives of – John Donne – Sir Henry Wotton – Richard Hooker – George Herbert & Robert Sanderson'' * [[Virginia Woolf|Woolf, Virginia]], ''The Common Reader'', 1932.
==Adaptations==
===Television=== [[Hugh Whitemore]] adapted ''84, Charing Cross Road'' for the BBC's ''[[Play for Today]]'', a television anthology series. It was first broadcast on 4 November 1975, starring [[Frank Finlay]] and [[Anne Jackson]].
===Theatre=== In 1981, [[James Roose-Evans]] adapted it for the stage in a two-character version first produced at the [[Salisbury Playhouse]] with [[Rosemary Leach]] and [[David Swift (actor)|David Swift]]. It transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]], where it opened to universally ecstatic reviews. A second production at the Playhouse ran from 5–28 February 2015, with [[Clive Francis]] and [[Janie Dee]] in the lead roles.<ref>{{cite book|title=84 Charing Cross Road Programme|publisher=The Salisbury Playhouse|date=2015}}</ref>
After fifteen previews, the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production opened to mixed reviews<ref>[http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9903EEDC1E39F93BA35751C1A964948260 ''New York Times'' review]</ref> on 7 December 1982 at the [[Nederlander Theatre]] with [[Ellen Burstyn]] and [[Joseph Maher]]. It ran for 96 performances.
===Radio=== Virginia Browns adapted the story for BBC Radio drama, and it was broadcast on Radio 3 on 15 January 1976, with Margaret Robertson as Hanff and Lyndon Brook as Doel. The play was produced by Christopher Venning.
James Roose-Evans again adapted the play for a 2007 radio production starring [[Gillian Anderson]] and [[Denis Lawson]], broadcast on Christmas Day on [[BBC Radio 4]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/nov/29/bbc.radio?gusrc=rss&feed=media|title=X Files star Gillian Anderson to appear in Radio 4 play|author=John Plunkett|work=the Guardian|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref>
===Film=== {{main|84 Charing Cross Road (film)}} Whitemore returned to the project to write the [[screenplay]] for the [[84 Charing Cross Road (film)|1987 film adaptation]] starring [[Anne Bancroft]] and [[Anthony Hopkins]]. The ''dramatis personae'' were expanded to include Hanff's [[Manhattan]] friends, the bookshop staff, and Doel's wife Nora, played by [[Judi Dench]]. Bancroft won a [[BAFTA]] Award as Best Actress; Whitemore and Dench were nominated for Director and Supporting Actress, respectively.
The Chinese-Hong Kong film ''Book of Love'' or ''[[Finding Mr. Right 2]]'' (Chinese: 北京遇上西雅圖之不二情書) (2016) references, and is loosely inspired by, ''84, Charing Cross Road''.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0072593|title=84 Charing Cross Road – Play for Today, 1975}} * {{IMDb title|id=0090570|title=84 Charing Cross Road – film, 1987}} * [http://www.84charingcrossroad.co.uk Marks & Co]

revision.comment: clean up, replaced: Curator:The Museums Journal → Curator: The Museum Journal
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}}
[[File:ISGardnerMuseum.JPG|thumb|The [[Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum]] was [[Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum theft|robbed in 1990]] with the paintings and items stolen valued at over $500 million.]]
'''Art theft''' is usually for the purpose of resale or for [[ransom]] (sometimes called '''artnapping'''). Stolen art is sometimes used by criminals as [[Collateral (finance)|collateral]] to secure loans.<ref>{{cite news|first=Nick |last=Hopkins |title=How art treasures are stolen to order |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/jan/08/nickhopkins |work=The Guardian |date=January 8, 2000 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160316154211/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/jan/08/nickhopkins |archivedate=March 16, 2016}}</ref> Only a small percentage of stolen art is recovered—estimates range from 5 to 10%. This means that little is known about the scope and characteristics of art theft.
==Individual theft== Many thieves are motivated by the fact that valuable art pieces are worth millions of dollars and weigh only a few kilograms at most. Transport for items such as paintings is also trivial, assuming the thief is willing to inflict some damage to the painting by cutting it off the frame and rolling it up into a tube carrier.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed|date=July 2011}} Also, while most high-profile museums have extremely tight security, many places with multimillion-dollar art collections have disproportionately poor security measures.<ref>{{cite news|first=Cameron |last=Skene |title=Art theft ranked as fourth-largest criminal enterprise |url=http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=40babe8f-84b5-46d7-a311-344494e03788 |work=National Post |location=Canada |date=September 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303174559/http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=40babe8f-84b5-46d7-a311-344494e03788 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df=mdy}}</ref> That makes them susceptible to thefts that are slightly more complicated than a typical [[smash-and-grab]], but offer a huge potential payoff. Thieves sometimes target works based on their own familiarity with the artist, rather than the artist's reputation in the art world or the theoretical value of the work.<ref name="rembrandts" />
Unfortunately for the thieves, it is extremely difficult to sell the most famous and valuable works without getting caught, because any interested buyer will almost certainly know the work is stolen and advertising it risks someone contacting the authorities. It is also difficult for the buyer to display the work to visitors without it being recognized as stolen, thus defeating much of the point of owning the art. Many famous works have instead been held for ransom from the legitimate owner or even returned without ransom, due to the lack of black-market customers. Returning for ransom also risks a [[sting operation]].<ref name="rembrandts">{{cite book|title=Stealing Rembrandts: The Untold Stories of Notorious Art Heists|author1=Anthony M. Amore|author2=Tom Mashberg|isbn=978-0230339903|year=2012}}</ref>
[[Image:Cholmondeley Oudry White Duck.jpg|thumb|right|[[Jean-Baptiste Oudry]]'s ''The White Duck'', which was stolen in 1990]] For those with substantial collections, such as the [[David Cholmondeley, 7th Marquess of Cholmondeley|Marquess of Cholmondeley]] at [[Houghton Hall]], the risk of theft is neither negligible nor negotiable.<ref>Bryant, Chris. [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article2085194.ece "Heritage for sale,"] ''Times'' (London). July 17, 2007.</ref> [[Jean-Baptiste Oudry]]'s ''White Duck '' was stolen from the Cholmondeley collection at Houghton Hall in 1990. The canvas is still missing.<ref>Lyall, Sarah. [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/19/arts/arts-abroad-a-titian-is-no-longer-at-large-its-thief-is.html?scp=17&sq=cholmondeley&st=nyt "A Titian Is No Longer at Large; Its Thief Is,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304094752/http://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/19/arts/arts-abroad-a-titian-is-no-longer-at-large-its-thief-is.html?scp=17&sq=cholmondeley&st=nyt |date=March 4, 2016}} ''New York Times.'' September 19, 2002.</ref>
==Prevention in museums== Museums can take numerous measures to prevent the theft of artworks include having enough guides or guards to watch displayed items, avoiding situations where security-camera sightlines are blocked, and fastening paintings to walls with hanging wires that are not too thin and with locks.<ref name=rkhhii/>
=== Art theft education === The Smithsonian Institution sponsors the National Conference on Cultural Property Protection, held annually in Washington, D. C. The conference is aimed at professionals in the field of cultural property protection.
Since 1996, the Netherlands-based Museum Security Network has disseminated news and information related to issues of cultural property loss and recovery. Since its founding the Museum Security Network has collected and disseminated over 45,000 reports about incidents with cultural property. The founder of the Museum Security Network, Ton Cremers, is recipient of the National Conference on Cultural Property Protection Robert Burke Award.
2007 saw the foundation of the Association for Research into Crimes against Art (ARCA). ARCA is a nonprofit [[think tank]] dedicated principally to raising the profile of art crime ([[art forgery]] and [[vandalism]], as well as theft) as an academic subject. Since 2009, ARCA has offered an unaccredited postgraduate certificate program dedicated to this field of study. The [[Postgraduate Certificate Program in Art Crime and Cultural Heritage Protection]] is held from June to August every year in Italy. A few American universities, including [http://arthistory.as.nyu.edu/page/home New York University], also offer courses on art crime.
==Recovery==
In the public sphere, [[Interpol]], the [[FBI]] Art Crime Team, London's [[Metropolitan Police]], [[New York Police Department]]'s special frauds squad<ref>Yarrow, Andrew L. [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/arts/a-lucrative-crime-grows-into-a-costly-epidemic.html?scp=10&sq=international%20foundatin%20for%20art%20research&st=cse "A Lucrative Crime Grows Into a Costly Epidemic,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228031853/http://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/arts/a-lucrative-crime-grows-into-a-costly-epidemic.html?scp=10&sq=international%20foundatin%20for%20art%20research&st=cse |date=December 28, 2016}} ''New York Times.'' March 20, 1990.</ref> and a number of other law enforcement agencies worldwide maintain "squads" dedicated to investigating thefts of this nature and recovering stolen works of art.
According to [[Robert King Wittman]], a former FBI agent who led the Art Crime Team until his retirement in 2008, the unit is very small compared with similar law-enforcement units in Europe, and most art thefts investigated by the FBI involve agents at local offices who handle routine property theft. "Art and antiquity crime is tolerated, in part, because it is considered a victimless crime," Wittman said in 2010.<ref name=rkhhii>Kennedy, Randy, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/07/arts/design/07wittman.html?ref=arts "His Heart Is in the Art of Sleuthing"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160209034311/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/07/arts/design/07wittman.html?ref=arts |date=February 9, 2016}}, p C1, ''The New York Times'', June 7, 2010, retrieved same day</ref>
In response to a growing public awareness of art theft and recovery, a number of not-for-profit and private companies now act both to record information about losses and oversee recovery efforts for claimed works of art. Among the most notable are:
* [[International Foundation for Art Research|IFAR]] * [[Commission for Looted Art in Europe]] * [[Holocaust Claims Conference]] * [[Art Loss Register]] * [[Art Recovery Group]]
In January 2017, Spain's [[Interior Ministry]] announced that police from 18 European countries, with the support of Interpol, [[Europol]], and [[Unesco]], had arrested 75 people involved in an international network of art traffickers. The pan-European operation had begun in October, 2016 and led to the recovery of about 3,500 stolen items including archaeological artifacts and other artwork. The ministry did not provide an inventory of recovered items or the locations of the arrests.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/22/world/europe/75-arrested-in-european-crackdown-on-art-trafficking.html?emc=edit_ee_20170123&nl=todaysheadlines-europe&nlid=62598762 |title=75 Arrested in European Crackdown on Art Trafficking |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 22, 2017 |author=Raphael Minder |accessdate=January 23, 2017}}</ref>
==State theft, wartime looting and misappropriation by museums== From 1933 through the end of World War II, the [[Nazi]] regime maintained a policy of [[Nazi plunder|looting art]] for sale or for removal to museums in the Third Reich. [[Hermann Göring]], head of the [[Luftwaffe]], personally took charge of hundreds of valuable pieces, generally stolen from Jews and other victims of [[the Holocaust]].
In early 2011, about 1,500 art masterpieces, assumed to have been stolen by the [[Nazis]] during and before World War II, were confiscated from a private home in Munich, Germany. The confiscation was not made public until November 2013.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/05/arts/design/trove-of-apparently-nazi-looted-art-found-in-munich-apartment.html?_r=0 "Report of Nazi-Looted Trove Puts Art World in an Uproar"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205111313/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/05/arts/design/trove-of-apparently-nazi-looted-art-found-in-munich-apartment.html?_r=0 |date=February 5, 2017}}, ''The New York Times'', Nov. 4, 2013</ref> With an estimated value of $1 billion, their discovery is considered "astounding,"<ref>video: [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/10424791/Expert-stolen-Nazi-art-find-astounding.html "Expert: stolen Nazi art find 'astounding'"], ''The Telegraph'', U.K., Nov. 4, 2013</ref> and includes works by [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Henri Matisse]], [[Marc Chagall]], [[Paul Klee]], [[Max Beckmann]] and [[Emil Nolde]], all of which were considered lost.<ref name=guardian>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/03/nazis-looted-modernist-masterpieces-germany-police "Modernist art haul, 'looted by Nazis', recovered by German police"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105213919/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/03/nazis-looted-modernist-masterpieces-germany-police |date=November 5, 2013}}, ''The Guardian'', U.K. Nov. 3, 2013</ref>
The looted, mostly [[Modern art|Modernist]] art, was banned by the Nazis when they came to power, on the grounds that it was "un-German" or Jewish Bolshevist in nature.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/10425983/Nazi-art-does-Germany-have-a-problem-returning-art-stolen-by-the-Nazis.html "Nazi art: does Germany have a problem returning art stolen by the Nazis?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106020130/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/10425983/Nazi-art-does-Germany-have-a-problem-returning-art-stolen-by-the-Nazis.html |date=November 6, 2013}}, ''The Telegraph'', U.K., Nov. 4, 2013</ref> Descendants of Jewish collectors who were robbed of their works by the Nazis may be able to claim ownership of many of the works.<ref name=guardian/> Members of the families of the original owners of [[looted art|these artworks]] have, in many cases, persisted in claiming title to their pre-war property.
The 1964 film [[The Train (1964 film)|''The Train'']], starring [[Burt Lancaster]], is based on the true story of works of art which had been placed in storage for protection in France during the war, but was looted by the Germans from French museums and private art collections, to be shipped by train back to Germany. Another film, ''[[The Monuments Men]]'' (2014), co-produced, co-written and directed by [[George Clooney]], is based on a similar true-life story. In this film, U.S. soldiers are tasked with saving over a million pieces of art and other culturally important items throughout Europe, before their destruction by [[Nazi plunder]].
In 2006, after a protracted court battle in the United States and Austria (see [[Republic of Austria v. Altmann]]), five paintings by [[Austrians|Austrian]] artist [[Gustav Klimt]] were returned to [[Maria Altmann]], the niece of pre-war owner, Ferdinand Bloch-Bauer. Two of the paintings were portraits of Altmann's aunt, Adele. The more famous of the two, the gold ''[[Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I]]'', was sold in 2006 by Altmann and her co-heirs to philanthropist [[Ronald Lauder]] for $135 million. At the time of the sale, it was the highest known price ever paid for a painting. The remaining four [[Restitution|restituted]] paintings were later sold at [[Christie's East|Christie's New York]] for over $190 million.
Because antiquities are often regarded by the country of origin as national treasures, there are numerous cases where artworks (often displayed in the acquiring country for decades) have become the subject of highly charged and political controversy. One prominent example is the case of the [[Elgin Marbles]], which were moved from Greece to the [[British Museum]] in 1816 by [[Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin]]. Many different [[Greece|Greek]] governments have maintained that removal was tantamount to theft.<ref>{{cite news |first=Summer |last=Banks |title=Now you see it, now you don't |date=January 25, 2008 |url =http://www.yaledailynews.com/articles/view/23119 |work =Yale Daily News |accessdate=January 27, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080129122413/http://www.yaledailynews.com/articles/view/23119 |archivedate=January 29, 2008}}</ref>
Similar controversies have arisen over [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]], [[Aztec]], and [[Italian art|Italian]] artworks, with advocates of the originating countries generally alleging that the removal of artifacts is a pernicious form of [[cultural imperialism]]. [[Yale University]]'s [[Peabody Museum of Natural History]] is engaged (as of November 2006) in talks with the government of [[Peru]] about possible [[Art repatriation|repatriation]] of [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] taken during the excavation of [[Machu Picchu]] by Yale's [[Hiram Bingham III|Hiram Bingham]]. Likewise the Chinese government considers Chinese art in foreign hands to be stolen and there may be a clandestine repatriation effort underway.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Palmer |first1=Alex W |title=The Great Chinese Art Heist |url=https://www.gq.com/story/the-great-chinese-art-heist |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=[[GQ]] |date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2006, New York's [[Metropolitan Museum]] reached an agreement with Italy to return many [[illicit antiquities|disputed pieces]]. The [[Getty Museum]] in Los Angeles is also involved in a [[Marion True|series of cases]] of this nature. The artwork in question is of Greek and ancient Italian origin. The museum agreed on November 20, 2006, to return 26 contested pieces to Italy. One of the Getty's signature pieces, a statue of the goddess [[Aphrodite]], is the subject of particular scrutiny.
In January 2013, after investigations by Interpol, FBI and The U.S. Department of Homeland Security, police in Canada arrested [[John Tillmann (art thief)]] for an enormous spate of art thefts. It was later determined that Tillmann in conjunction with his Russian wife, had for over twenty years, stolen at least 10,000 different art objects from various museums, galleries, archives and shops from around the world. While not the largest art heist in total dollar value, Tillmann's case may be the largest art heist ever, in number of objects stolen.
==Famous cases of art theft== {{See also|List of stolen paintings|Aydın Dikmen}}
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- ! style="width:100px;"|Case of art theft ! style="width:100px;"|Dates !class="unsortable"|Notes ! style="width:75px;" class="unsortable"|References |- |[[Louvre]] |August 21, 1911 | {{main|Mona Lisa#Theft and vandalism}} Perhaps the most famous case of art theft occurred on August 21, 1911, when the ''[[Mona Lisa]]'' was stolen from the [[Louvre]] by employee [[Vincenzo Peruggia]], who was caught after two years. |<ref name="monalisa25">''Time Magazine'', [https://web.archive.org/web/20070303065050/http://www.time.com/time/2007/crimes/2.html ''Stealing the Mona Lisa, 1911'']. Consulted on August 15, 2007.</ref> |- |Panels from the ''[[Ghent Altarpiece]]'' |1934 |Two panels of the fifteenth century ''[[Ghent Altarpiece]]'', painted by the brothers [[Jan van Eyck|Jan]] and [[Hubert van Eyck|Hubert Van Eyck]] were stolen in 1934, of which only one was recovered shortly after the theft. The other one (lower left of the opened altarpiece, known as ''De Rechtvaardige Rechters'' i.e. ''[[The Just Judges]]''), has never been recovered, as the presumable thief ([[Arsène Goedertier]]), who had sent some anonymous letters asking for ransom, died before revealing the whereabouts of the painting. | |- |[[Nazi plunder|Nazi theft and looting of Europe during the Second World War]] |1939–1945 | {{Main|Nazi plunder}} The [[Nazi plunder]]ing of artworks was carried out by the [[Reichsleiter Rosenberg Institute for the Occupied Territories]] (Einsatzstab Reichsleiter Rosenberg für die Besetzen Gebiete). In occupied France, the [[Galerie nationale du Jeu de Paume|Jeu de Paume Art Museum]] in Paris was used as a central storage and sorting depot for looted artworks from museums and private [[art collection]]s throughout France pending distribution to various persons and places in Germany. The Nazis confiscated tens of thousands of works from their legitimate Jewish owners. Some were confiscated by the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] at the end of the war. Many ended up in the hands of respectable collectors and institutions. Jewish ownership of some of the art was codified into the [[Geneva conventions]]. | |- |[[Theft of medieval art from Quedlinburg|Quedlinburg medieval artifacts]] |1945 | {{Main|Theft of medieval art from Quedlinburg}} In 1945, an American soldier Joe Meador stole eight medieval artifacts found in a mineshaft near [[Quedlinburg]] which had been hidden by local members of the clergy from Nazi looters in 1943.
Returning to the United States, the artifacts remained in Meador's possession until his death in 1980. He made no attempt to sell them. When his older brother and sister attempted to sell a 9th-century manuscript and 16th-century prayer book in 1990, the two were charged. However, the charges were dismissed after it was declared the [[statute of limitations]] had expired. | |- |Alfred Stieglitz Gallery |1946 | Three paintings by [[Georgia O'Keeffe]] were stolen while on display at the art gallery of her husband, [[Alfred Stieglitz]]. The paintings were eventually found by O'Keeffe following their purchase by the [[Princeton Gallery of Fine Arts]] for $35,000 in 1975. O'Keeffe sued the museum for their return and, despite a six-year statute of limitations on art theft, a state appellate court ruled in her favor on July 27, 1979. | |- |Dulwich College Picture Gallery |December 30, 1966 | A total of eight [[Old Master]] paintings—three each by [[Rembrandt]] and [[Peter Paul Rubens]], and one each by [[Adam Elsheimer]] and [[Gerrit Dou]]—were removed from this London gallery. The paintings were appraised at a combined value of £1.5 million (then US$4.2 million). The thieves entered the gallery by cutting a panel out of an unused door. All of the paintings were recovered by January 4, 1967. | |- |[[University of Michigan]] |1967 | Sketches by Spanish artist [[Pablo Picasso]] and British sculptor [[Henry Moore]], valued at $200,000, were stolen while on display in a travelling art exhibit organized by the [[University of Michigan]]. The sketches were eventually found by federal agents in a California auction house on January 24, 1969, although no arrests were made. | |- |Izmir Archaeology Museum |July 24, 1969 | Various artifacts and other art worth $5 million were stolen from the Izmir Archaeology Museum in [[Istanbul, Turkey]] on July 24, 1969 (during which a night watchman was killed by the unidentified thieves). Turkish police soon arrested a German citizen who, at the time of his arrest on August 1, had 128 stolen items in his car. | |- |Stephen Hahn Art Gallery |November 17, 1969 | Art thieves stole seven paintings, including works by [[Mary Cassatt|Cassatt]], [[Monet]], [[Pissarro]] and [[Rouault]], from art dealer [[Stephen Hahn (art dealer)|Stephen Hahn]]'s Madison Avenue art gallery at an estimated value of $500,000 on the night of November 17, 1969. Incidentally, Stephen Hahn had been discussing art theft with other art dealers as the theft was taking place. | |- |[[1972 Montreal Museum of Fine Arts robbery]] |September 4, 1972 | On September 4, 1972, the [[Montreal Museum of Fine Arts]] was the site of the largest art theft in Canadian history, when armed thieves made off with jewelry, figurines and 18 paintings worth a total of $2 million (approximately $10.9 million today), including works by [[Eugène Delacroix|Delacroix]], [[Thomas Gainsborough|Gainsborough]] and a rare [[Rembrandt]] landscape. Other than a work at the time attributed to [[Jan Brueghel the Elder|Brueghel the Elder]] returned by the thieves as an effort to start negotiations, the works have never been recovered. In 2003, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' estimated that the Rembrandt alone would be worth $1 million. |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.cbc.ca/on_this_day/09/04/ |title=CBC Digital Archives, ''Art heist at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts'' |publisher=Archives.cbc.ca |accessdate=May 21, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229180655/http://archives.cbc.ca/on_this_day/09/04/ |archivedate=December 29, 2010}}</ref> |- |[[Russborough House]] |1974–2002 | [[Russborough House]], the Irish estate of the late Sir [[Alfred Lane Beit|Alfred Beit]], has been robbed four times since 1974.
In 1974, members of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army|IRA]], including [[Rose Dugdale]], bound and gagged the Beits, making off with nineteen paintings worth an estimated £8 million. A deal to exchange the paintings for prisoners was offered, but the paintings were recovered after a raid on a rented cottage in [[County Cork|Cork]], and those responsible were caught and imprisoned.
In 1986, a [[Dublin]] gang led by [[Martin Cahill]] stole eighteen paintings worth an estimated £30 million in total. Sixteen paintings were subsequently recovered, with a further two still missing {{as of|2006}}.
Two paintings worth an estimated £3 million were stolen by three armed men in 2001. One of these, a [[Thomas Gainsborough|Gainsborough]] had been previously stolen by Cahill's gang. Both paintings were recovered in September 2002.
A mere two to three days after the recovery of the two paintings stolen in 2001, the house was robbed for the fourth time, with five paintings taken. These paintings were recovered in December 2002 during a search of a house in [[Clondalkin]]. | |- |Kanakria mosaics and the looting of Cypriot Orthodox Churches following the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus|invasion of Cyprus]] |1974 | Following the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus|invasion of Cyprus]] in 1974 by [[Turkey]], and the occupation of the northern part of the island churches belonging to the [[Cypriot Orthodox Church]] have been looted in what is described as ''"…one of the most systematic examples of the looting of art since World War II"''.<ref>{{cite news|first=Chris |last=Morris |title=Shame of Cyprus's looted churches |date=January 18, 2002 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1768274.stm |work=BBC |accessdate=January 29, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040308215100/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1768274.stm |archivedate=March 8, 2004}}</ref> Several high-profile cases have made headline news on the international scene. Most notable was the case of the Kanakaria mosaics, 6th century AD frescoes that were removed from the original church, trafficked to the USA and offered for sale to a museum for the sum of US$20,000,000. These were subsequently recovered by the Orthodox Church following a court case in Indianapolis. |<ref>{{cite journal|title=Litigators of the lost art – court orders return of Byzantine mosaics to their homeland|journal=Saturday Evening Post|date=October 1989|first=Steve|last=Mannheimer|id= |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-7980763.html|format= – <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3AMannheimer+intitle%3ALitigators+of+the+lost+art+-+court+orders+return+of+Byzantine+mosaics+to+their+homeland&as_publication=Saturday+Evening+Post&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup>|accessdate=January 29, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bourloyannis|first=Christiane|date=January 1992|title=Autocephalous Greek-Orthodox Church of Cyrprus v. Goldberg & Feldman Fine Arts, Inc|journal=The American Journal of International Law|publisher=American Society of International Law|volume=86|issue=1|pages=128–133|doi=10.2307/2203143|jstor=2203143|author2=Virginia Morris}}<!--|accessdate=January 29, 2007--></ref> |- |Picasso works in the [[Palais des Papes]] |January 31, 1976 | On January 31, 1976, 118 paintings, drawings and other works by Picasso were stolen from an exhibition at the [[Palais des Papes]] in [[Avignon]], France. |<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6403837.stm |title=Picasso paintings stolen in Paris |publisher=BBC News |date=February 28, 2007 |accessdate=May 21, 2010 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100410030053/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6403837.stm| archivedate=April 10, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=CBC Arts |url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/artdesign/story/2007/02/28/picassostolen.html |title=Picasso works stolen from artist's granddaughter |publisher=CBC |date=February 28, 2007 |accessdate=May 21, 2010 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100525214417/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/artdesign/story/2007/02/28/picassostolen.html| archivedate=May 25, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-societe/2010-05-20/chronologie-les-principaux-vols-de-tableaux-dans-des-musees-francais/920/0/457043 |title=Chronologie – Les vols de tableaux dans des musées français |work=Le Point |accessdate=May 21, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524160640/http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-societe/2010-05-20/chronologie-les-principaux-vols-de-tableaux-dans-des-musees-francais/920/0/457043 |archivedate=May 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> |- |[[L. A. Mayer Institute for Islamic Art]] |April 15, 1983 | On April 15, 1983, more than 200 rare clocks and watches were stolen from the [[L. A. Mayer Institute for Islamic Art]] in [[Jerusalem]]. Among the stolen watches was one known as the [[Marie-Antoinette]], the most valuable piece of the watch collection made by the French-Swiss watchmaker [[Abraham-Louis Breguet]] on order by Queen [[Marie Antoinette]], it is estimated to be worth $30 million. The heist is considered to be the largest robbery in Israel. The man responsible for the robbery was [[Naaman Diller]]. On November 18, 2008, French and Israeli police officials discovered half of the cache of stolen timepieces in two bank safes in France. Of the 106 rare timepieces stolen in 1983, 96 have now been recovered. Among those recovered was the rare Marie-Antoinette watch. In 2010, Nilli Shomrat, Diller's widow, was sentenced to 300 hours of community service and given a five-year suspended sentence for possession of stolen property. |<ref name="haaretz1">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/widow-of-man-behind-fabled-watch-robbery-convicted-in-u-s-court-1.264092 |title=Widow of man behind fabled watch robbery convicted in U.S. court |publisher=[[Haaretz]] |date=April 3, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106112614/http://www.haaretz.com/widow-of-man-behind-fabled-watch-robbery-convicted-in-u-s-court-1.264092 |archivedate=January 6, 2016}}</ref><ref name="haaretz1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museum-security.org/?p=664 |title=43 rare clocks stolen from Israel found in France |date=April 3, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927221755/http://www.museum-security.org/?p=664 |archivedate=September 27, 2011}}</ref> |- |[[Musée Marmottan Monet]] |October 28, 1985 | {{main|Musée Marmottan Monet#1985 theft}} On October 28, 1985, during daylight hours, five masked gunmen with [[pistol]]s at the security and visitors entered the museum and stole nine paintings from the collection. Among them were ''[[Impression, Sunrise]] (Impression, Soleil Levant)'' by [[Claude Monet]], the painting from which the [[Impressionism]] movement took from. Aside from that also stolen were ''Camille Monet and Cousin on the Beach at Trouville'', ''Portrait of Jean Monet,'' ''Portrait of Poly, Fisherman of Belle-Isle'' and ''Field of Tulips in Holland'' also by Monet, ''Bather Sitting on a Rock'' and ''Portrait of Monet'' by [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]], ''Young Woman at the Ball'' by [[Berthe Morisot]], and ''Portrait of Monet'' by [[Sei-ichi Naruse]] and were valued at $12 million.<ref name="times">{{cite news|last=Cook|first=Don|title=9 Masterworks, 5 by Monet, Seized in Paris – Gunmen Stage "Art Theft of the Century"|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-10-28/news/mn-11672_1_claude-monet|accessdate=November 16, 2010|newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=October 28, 1985| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101206155320/http://articles.latimes.com/1985-10-28/news/mn-11672_1_claude-monet| archivedate= December 6, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The paintings were later recovered in [[Corsica]] in 1990.<ref name="forbes">{{cite news|title=The World's Greatest Art Heists |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/02/12/art-theft-museums-biz-cx_af_0212artheists.html |accessdate=November 16, 2010 |magazine=[[Forbes]] |date=February 12, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125022359/http://www.forbes.com/2008/02/12/art-theft-museums-biz-cx_af_0212artheists.html |archivedate=November 25, 2010}}</ref> | |- |[[University of Arizona Museum of Art]] |November 27, 1985 |A couple who arrived at the museum shortly before it opened for the day left ten minutes later. Guards found shortly afterwards that [[Willem de Kooning]]'s ''[[Woman-Ochre]]'' had been cut from its frame; sketches were made of the couple but the investigation was unable to make any progress until 2017, when a [[New Mexico]] antique dealer found the painting in the home of a recently-deceased woman for whom he had been contracted to hold an [[estate sale]]. After his customers told him the painting was likely a de Kooning, he found that it had been stolen in 1987 during an Internet search. He contacted the museum, which sent staff the next day to pick it up.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/09/nyregion/a-de-kooning-a-theft-and-an-enduring-mystery.html|title=A de Kooning, a Theft and an Enduring Mystery|last=Rashbaum|first=William|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 9, 2017|accessdate=September 19, 2018}}</ref> | |- |[[Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum]] |March 18, 1990 | {{main|Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum theft}} The largest art theft, and the largest theft of any private property, in world history occurred in Boston on March 18, 1990 when thieves stole 13 pieces, collectively worth $300 million, from the [[Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum]]. A reward of $5,000,000 was on offer for information leading to their return, but expired at the end of 2017.
The pieces stolen were: [[Vermeer]]'s ''[[The Concert (Vermeer)|The Concert]]'', which is the most valuable stolen painting in the world; two [[Rembrandt]] paintings, ''[[The Storm on the Sea of Galilee]]'' (his only known seascape) and ''[[Portrait of a Lady and Gentleman in Black]]''; A Rembrandt self-portrait etching; [[Manet]]'s ''[[Chez Tortoni]]''; five drawings by [[Edgar Degas]]; [[Govaert Flinck]]'s ''[[Landscape with an Obelisk]]''; an ancient Chinese Qu; and a [[finial]] that once stood atop a flag from Napoleon's Army. | |- |''[[The Scream]]'' <br> ([[National Museum of Art, Architecture and Design]]) |February 12, 1994 | {{main|The Scream#Thefts}} In 1994, [[Edvard Munch]]'s ''[[The Scream]]'' was stolen from the National Gallery in [[Oslo]], Norway, and held for ransom. It was recovered later in the year. | |- |[[Frankfurt art theft (1994)|Kunsthalle Schirn]] |July 28, 1994 | {{main|Frankfurt art theft (1994)}} Three paintings were stolen from a German gallery in 1994, two of them belonging to the [[Tate Gallery]] in London. In 1998, Tate conceived of ''Operation Cobalt'', the secret buyback of the paintings from the thieves. The paintings were recovered in 2000 and 2002, resulting in a profit of several million pounds for Tate, because of prior insurance payments. | |- |[[Mather Brown]]'s ''Thomas Jefferson'' |July 28, 1994 | While being stored in preparation to be reproduced, the portrait of ''[[Thomas Jefferson]]'' painted by artist [[Mather Brown]] in 1786, was stolen from a Boston warehouse on July 28, 1994. Authorities apprehended the thieves and recovered the painting on May 24, 1996 following a protracted FBI investigation. | |- |[[Sofia Imber Museum of Contemporary Art]] (MACCSI) |1999-2000 | The work of [[Henri Matisse]] Odalisque with red trousers, dating back to 1925 was stolen from the museum and replaced by a bad imitation, this work valued at ten million dollars was recovered in 2012 and returned to the institution two years later. | |- |Cooperman Art Theft hoax |1999 | In July 1999, Los Angeles ophthalmologist [[Steven Cooperman]] was convicted of [[insurance fraud]] for arranging the theft of two paintings, a [[Picasso]] and a [[Monet]], from his home in an attempt to collect $17.5 million in insurance. | |- |[[Nationalmuseum]] |December 22, 2000 | One [[Rembrandt]] and two [[Renoir]] paintings were stolen from the [[Nationalmuseum]] in Stockholm, Sweden, after three armed thieves, who had diverted the attention of police by setting off two separate [[car bomb]]s nearby beforehand, broke into the museum and fled using a boat, moored nearby. By 2001, the police had recovered one of the Renoirs and by March 2005 they had recovered the second one in Los Angeles. That year, in September, they recovered the Rembrandt in a sting operation in a hotel in Copenhagen. |<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4252568.stm |title=Stolen Rembrandt work recovered |publisher=BBC News |date=September 16, 2005 |accessdate=September 21, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100910001921/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4252568.stm| archivedate= September 10, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl=no}}</ref> |- |[[Stephane Breitwieser]] |2001 | {{main|Stephane Breitwieser}} [[Stephane Breitwieser]] admitted to stealing 238 artworks and other exhibits from museums travelling around Europe; his motive was to build a vast personal collection. In January 2005, Breitwieser was given a 26-month prison sentence. Unfortunately, over 60 paintings, including masterpieces by [[Pieter Brueghel the Younger|Brueghel]], [[Watteau]], [[François Boucher]], and [[Corneille de Lyon]] were chopped up by Breitwieser's mother, Mireille Stengel, in what police believe was an effort to remove incriminating evidence against her son. |<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2002/05/17/MN166733.DTL |title=Art 'collector' arrested / Frenchman's mother accused of destroying pieces stolen from museums all over Europe |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=May 17, 2002 |accessdate=May 21, 2010 |first=Alan |last=Riding |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604032832/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2002%2F05%2F17%2FMN166733.DTL |archivedate=June 4, 2011}}</ref> |- |[[Van Gogh Museum]] |December 8, 2002 |{{main|Van Gogh Museum#Art thefts}} The two paintings ''[[Congregation Leaving the Reformed Church in Nuenen]]'' and ''[[View of the Sea at Scheveningen]]'' by [[Vincent van Gogh]] were stolen from the [[Van Gogh Museum]] in Amsterdam, Netherlands. Two men were convicted for the theft. The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] Art Crime Team estimates their combined value at US$30{{nbsp}}million. The paintings were recovered from the [[Camorra|Naples mafia]] in September 2016 following a raid on a house at [[Castellammare di Stabia]], near [[Pompeii]]. |<ref>"[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/08/world/two-van-gogh-works-are-stolen-in-amsterdam.html Two van Gogh Works Are Stolen in Amsterdam] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170326193034/http://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/08/world/two-van-gogh-works-are-stolen-in-amsterdam.html |date=March 26, 2017}}", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 2002. Retrieved February 23, 2012.</ref><ref>Lawrence Van Gelder, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/27/theater/arts-briefing.html Jail for Van Gogh Thieves] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019024217/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/27/theater/arts-briefing.html |date=October 19, 2015}}", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 2004. Retrieved February 23, 2012.</ref><ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/investigate/violent-crime/art-theft/fbi-top-ten-art-crimes/van-gogh-museum-robbery Van Gogh Museum Robbery] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414134200/https://www.fbi.gov/about-us/investigate/vc_majorthefts/arttheft/vangogh |date=April 14, 2016}}, [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]. Retrieved February 23, 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=[[BBC News]] |date=September 30, 2016 |accessdate=September 30, 2016 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-37516164 |title=Van Gogh paintings stolen from Amsterdam found in Italy |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160930083632/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-37516164 |archivedate=September 30, 2016}}</ref> |- |''[[The Scream]]'' and ''[[Madonna (Edvard Munch)|Madonna]]'' <br> ([[Munch Museum]]) |August 22, 2004 | {{main|The Scream#Thefts}} On August 22, 2004, another original of ''[[The Scream]]'' was stolen—Munch painted several versions of ''The Scream''—together with Munch's ''[[Madonna (Edvard Munch)|Madonna]]''. This time the thieves targeted the version held by the [[Munch Museum]], from where the two paintings were stolen at gunpoint and during opening hours. Both paintings were recovered on August 31, 2006, relatively undamaged. Three men have already been convicted, but the gunmen remain at large. If caught, they could face up to eight years in prison. |<ref>{{cite news |title=Stolen Munch paintings found safe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/5303200.stm |publisher=BBC|date=August 31, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Munch paintings recovered |date=August 31, 2006 |publisher=Aftenposten |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1441444.ece |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219221013/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1441444.ece |archivedate=February 19, 2008 |df=mdy}}</ref> |- |Munch paintings theft in Norway |March 6, 2005 | On March 6, 2005, three more Munch paintings were stolen from a hotel in Norway, including ''Blue Dress'', and were recovered the next day. |<ref>{{cite news|title=Stolen Munch art found in Norway |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/4324775.stm |publisher=BBC |date=March 7, 2005 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070127141925/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/4324775.stm |archivedate=January 27, 2007}}</ref> |- |[[Kunsthistorisches Museum]] |May 11, 2003 | {{main|Cellini Salt Cellar#Theft and return}} On May 11, 2003, [[Benvenuto Cellini]]'s ''[[Saliera]]'' was stolen from the [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]] in Vienna, which was covered by a [[scaffolding]] at that time due to reconstruction works. On January 21, 2006 the ''Saliera'' was recovered by the Austrian police. | |- |[[Henry Moore Foundation|Henry Moore Foundation Perry Green]] |December 15, 2005 | The artist's cast of ''[[Reclining Figure 1969–70]]'', a bronze sculpture of British sculptor [[Henry Moore]], was stolen from the Henry Moore Foundation's Perry Green base on December 15, 2005. Thieves are believed to have lifted the {{convert|3.6|xx|2|xx|2|m}} wide, 2.1-tonne statue onto the back of a Mercedes lorry using a crane. Police investigating the theft believe it could have been stolen for scrap value. |<ref> {{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/beds/bucks/herts/4537670.stm |title=£3m Henry Moore sculpture stolen |accessdate=February 10, 2008 |date=December 17, 2005 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010124828/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/beds/bucks/herts/4537670.stm |archivedate=October 10, 2007 }} </ref> |- |Museu da Chácara do Céu |February 24, 2006 | On February 24, 2006, the paintings ''Man of Sickly Complexion Listening to the Sound of the Sea'' by [[Salvador Dalí]], ''The Dance'' by [[Pablo Picasso]], ''Luxembourg Gardens'' by [[Henri Matisse]], and ''Marine'' by [[Claude Monet]] were stolen from the {{Interlanguage link multi|Museu da Chácara do Céu|pt}} in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The thieves took advantage of a carnival parade passing by the museum and disappeared into the crowd. The paintings haven't been recovered yet. |<ref>{{cite news |title= Monet stolen under carnival cover|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4749756.stm|publisher=BBC |date=February 25, 2006 |accessdate=February 14, 2010 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100127025340/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4749756.stm| archivedate= January 27, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl=no}}</ref> |- |[[São Paulo Museum of Art]] |December 20, 2007 | On December 20, 2007, around five o'clock in the morning, three men invaded the [[São Paulo Museum of Art]] and took two paintings, considered to be among the most valuable of the museum: the ''[[Portrait of Suzanne Bloch]]'' by [[Pablo Picasso]] and [[Cândido Portinari]]'s ''[http://ritualcafe.files.wordpress.com/2007/07/lavrador-de-cafe.jpg O lavrador de café]''. The whole action took about 3 minutes. The paintings, which are listed as Brazilian National Heritage by IPHAN,<ref>{{pt icon}} * IPHAN – Official Note {{cite web |url=http://www.cultura.gov.br/site/?p=9488 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=January 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019024220/http://www2.cultura.gov.br/site/?p=9488 |archivedate=October 19, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} – ''The paintings "O lavrador de Café", "Retrato de Suzanne Bloch" as well as the entire collection of MASP are considered Brazilian National Heritage since 1969 due to its importance to the culture of the country.</ref> remained missing until January 8, 2008, when they were recovered in [[Ferraz de Vasconcelos]] by the [[Polícia Militar do Estado de São Paulo|Police of São Paulo]]. The paintings were returned, undamaged, to the São Paulo Museum of Art.<ref name="YAHOO NEWS">{{cite news|author=MacSwan, Angus |title=Security questioned in Picasso theft in Brazil |url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/rtrs/20071221/ten-uk-brazil-picasso-d3877cb_1.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230164038/http://uk.news.yahoo.com/rtrs/20071221/ten-uk-brazil-picasso-d3877cb_1.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 30, 2007 |date=December 21, 2007 |agency=Reuters |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="USA TODAY">{{cite news |author=Winter, Michael |title=Stolen Picasso, Portinari recovered in Brazil|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/topstories/2008-01-08-2665206065_x.htm |date=January 8, 2008 |work=USA TODAY}}</ref> | |- |[[Foundation E.G. Bührle]] |February 11, 2008 | {{main|Foundation E.G. Bührle#Art theft}} On February 11, 2008, four major impressionist paintings were stolen from the [[Foundation E.G. Bührle]] in [[Zürich]], Switzerland. They were [[Monet]]'s ''Poppy Field at Vetheuil'', ''[[Ludovic Lepic and his Daughter]]'' by [[Edgar Degas]], [[Van Gogh]]'s ''[[Blossoming Chestnut Branches]]'', and [[Cézanne]]'s ''[[Boy in the Red Vest]]''. The total worth of the four is estimated at $163 million. |<ref>{{cite news|author1=Harnischfeger, Uta |author2=Bowley, Graham |title=4 Masterworks Stolen by Armed Robbers in Zurich |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/12/world/europe/12swiss.html?hp |date=February 11, 2008 |publisher=NY Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019024217/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/12/world/europe/12swiss.html?hp |archivedate=October 19, 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.outpost-art.org/blog/?p=255 2 Stolen Paintings Found by Swiss] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630214740/http://www.outpost-art.org/blog/?p=255 |date=June 30, 2015}}</ref> |- |[[Pinacoteca do Estado de São Paulo]] |June 12, 2008 | On June 12, 2008, three armed men broke into the [[Pinacoteca do Estado de São Paulo|Pinacoteca do Estado Museum]], São Paulo with a [[Crowbar (tool)|crowbar]] and a [[carjack]] around 5:09 am and stole ''The Painter and the Model'' (1963), and ''Minotaur, Drinker and Women'' (1933) by [[Pablo Picasso]], ''Women at the Window'' (1926) by [[Emiliano Di Cavalcanti]] and ''Couple'' (1919) by [[Lasar Segall]]. It was the second theft of art in São Paulo in six months. On August 6, 2008, two paintings was discovered in the house of one of thieves and recovered by police in same city. |<ref>{{cite news|title=Two Picassos stolen in Brazil |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7451986.stm |date=June 13, 2008 |publisher=BBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160220210739/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7451986.stm |archivedate=February 20, 2016}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|title=Thieves steal Picasso painting in Brazil |url=http://cynsheng.wordpress.com/2007/12/21/thieves-steal-picasso-painting-in-brazil/ |date=June 13, 2008 |publisher=Cynsheng |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305123848/https://cynsheng.wordpress.com/2007/12/21/thieves-steal-picasso-painting-in-brazil/ |archivedate=March 5, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Thieves steal Picassos, Brazilian works from São Paulo museum |url=http://www.france24.com/20080613-thieves-steal-picassos-brazilian-works-sao-paulo-museum |date=June 13, 2008 |publisher=France 24}} {{Dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Quadros recuperados devem voltar hoje para Pinacoteca |url=http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/Brasil/0,,MUL715197-5598,00-QUADROS+RECUPERADOS+DEVEM+VOLTAR+HOJE+PARA+PINACOTECA.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102221648/http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/Brasil/0%2C%2CMUL715197-5598%2C00-QUADROS%2BRECUPERADOS%2BDEVEM%2BVOLTAR%2BHOJE%2BPARA%2BPINACOTECA.html |deadurl=yes |archivedate=January 2, 2015 |date=August 7, 2008 |publisher=Globo.com}}</ref> |- |[[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]] |May 10, 2010 | {{main|Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris#2010 theft}} On May 20, 2010, the [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]] reported the overnight theft of five paintings from its collection. The paintings taken were ''[[Le pigeon aux petits pois]]'' by [[Pablo Picasso]], ''[[La Pastorale]]'' by [[Henri Matisse]], ''[[L'Olivier près de l'Estaque]]'' by [[Georges Braque]], ''{{Interlanguage link multi|La Femme à l'éventail (Modigliani)|fr}}'' by [[Amedeo Modigliani]] and ''[[Still Life with Candlestick|Still Life with Candlestick (Nature Morte aux Chandeliers)]]'' by [[Fernand Léger]] |Venus Over Manhattan |June 19, 2012 | {{main|Cartel de Don Juan Tenorio}} On June 19, 2012, [[Salvador Dalí]]'s ''[[Cartel de Don Juan Tenorio]]'' was stolen from the then month-old Venus Over Manhattan gallery in New York City. The theft was captured on tape. The drawing was mailed back to the gallery from Greece, and was displayed for the last day of a 10-day show. |<ref name="usnews">{{cite web|url=http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/06/22/12351244-150000-salvador-dali-painting-stolen-from-new-york-city-art-gallery|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625020345/http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/06/22/12351244-150000-salvador-dali-painting-stolen-from-new-york-city-art-gallery|archivedate=June 25, 2012 |title=$150,000 Salvador Dali painting stolen from New York City art gallery|publisher=MSNBC|date=June 22, 2012 |accessdate=December 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name="yahoo-abc">{{cite web |last=Newcomb |first=Alyssa |url=https://news.yahoo.com/stolen-salvador-dali-drawing-mysteriously-returned-mail-193512556--abc-news-topstories.html |title=Stolen Salvador Dali Drawing Mysteriously Returned by Mail |publisher=ABC News |date=June 30, 2012 |accessdate=December 21, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128061431/http://news.yahoo.com/stolen-salvador-dali-drawing-mysteriously-returned-mail-193512556--abc-news-topstories.html |archivedate=January 28, 2013 |df= }}</ref> |- |[[Dulwich Park]] |December 19–20, 2012 |A cast of [[Barbara Hepworth]]'s (5/6) ''[[Two Forms (Divided Circle)]]'' was displayed in Dulwich Park from 1970 until it was cut from it plinth by scrap metal thieves in December 2011. It was insured for £500,000, but its scrap value was estimated at perhaps £750. Southwark Council offered a reward of £1,000, and the Hepworth Estate increased the reward to £5,000, for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the thieves. |<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/very-grand-theft-barbara-hepworths-park-sculpture-is-stolen-for-scrap-metal-6279889.html Very grand theft: Barbara Hepworth's park sculpture is stolen for scrap metal ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141207060210/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/very-grand-theft-barbara-hepworths-park-sculpture-is-stolen-for-scrap-metal-6279889.html |date=December 7, 2014}}, The Independent, December 21, 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/dec/20/barbara-hepworth-sculpture-park-stolen Barbara Hepworth sculpture stolen from London park] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309174028/http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/dec/20/barbara-hepworth-sculpture-park-stolen |date=March 9, 2016}}, The Guardian, December 20, 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8968237/Barbara-Hepworth-500k-Two-Forms-sculpture-stolen-by-metal-thieves.html Barbara Hepworth: £500k 'Two Forms' sculpture stolen by metal thieves] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141202152739/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8968237/Barbara-Hepworth-500k-Two-Forms-sculpture-stolen-by-metal-thieves.html |date=December 2, 2014}}, The Telegraph, 20 December 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16266378 Barbara Hepworth sculpture stolen from Dulwich Park], BBC News, December 20, 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16319189 Reward for Hepworth art stolen from Dulwich Park increased], BBC News, December 23, 2011</ref> |- |[[Kunsthal]] |October 16, 2012 |{{main|Kunsthal#Art theft}} On October 16, 2012, seven paintings were stolen from the museum in [[Rotterdam]]. The paintings included [[Claude Monet|Monet]]'s ''Waterloo Bridge, London'' and ''Charing Cross Bridge, London'', [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]]'s ''Tete d'Arlequin'', [[Paul Gauguin|Gauguin]]'s ''Femme devant une fenêtre ouverte'', [[Henri Matisse|Matisse]]'s ''La Liseuse en Blanc et Jaune'', [[Meijer de Haan|De Haan]]'s ''Autoportrait'', and [[Lucian Freud]]'s ''Woman with Eyes Closed''. |<ref>{{cite news|last=Kreijger |first=Gilbert |title=Dutch art heist nets works by Monet, Picasso, Matisse |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/16/entertainment-us-crime-dutch-paintings-idUSBRE89F0OX20121016 |newspaper=Reuters |date=October 16, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710173728/https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/16/entertainment-us-crime-dutch-paintings-idUSBRE89F0OX20121016 |archivedate=July 10, 2015}}</ref>
|- |[[John Tillmann (art thief)]] |January 18, 2013 |{{main|John Tillmann (art thief)}} On January 18, 2013, police in Canada arrested John Mark Tillmann of Fall River Nova Scotia after extensive investigations by Interpol, FBI, RCMP and the US Dept of Homeland Security. The case was a mammoth one and it took authorities nearly three years to close the file. Tillmann was sentenced to nine years in prison for stealing over 10,000 pieces of art-work. In sheer volume, it may be the biggest case of art heist of all time. It was later determined that Tillmann had acted in concert with his Russian wife and her brother, and that they had travelled extensively over the world posing as security and maintenance workers to gain access to museums. Successfully eluding authorities for almost twenty years, the trio had stolen millions of dollars of artifacts in every continent except Australia. Tillmann and his accomplice wife, even raided the Nova Scotia Provincial Legislature in his home province, making off with a valuable 200 year old watercolour. He was versatile in his art thefts, not solely concentrating on paintings, but also known for stealing rare books, statutes, coins, edged weapons, medieval Knight suits of armour and even a 5,000 year old Egyptian mummy. A university graduate, he was also known to be an avid history buff. |<ref name="Huffington Post">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/news/tillman/ |title=Man Pulled over, Found To Be Prolific Art Thief |work=Huffington Post |date=January 24, 2013 |accessdate=January 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310213224/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/news/tillman/ |archivedate=March 10, 2016}}</ref> <ref>{{cite |- |Sripuranthan [[Chola]] Idols |January, 2006 |{{main|Sripuranthan Natarajan Idol}} In 2006, about 8 antique [[Chola]] idols, that of [[Nataraja]]r and Uma Mashewari, [[Ganesha|Vinayagar]], Devi, [[Lakshmi|Deepalaksmi]], Chandrashekarar, Sampanthar and [[Krishna]]r, were stolen from the Brihadeeswarar temple at Sripuranthan, allegedly on the orders of New York-based art dealer [[Subhash Kapoor (art dealer)|Subhash Kapoor]], and smuggled to the United States. Of these statues the Natarajar idol was sold to the [[National Gallery of Australia]], Canberra for USD 5.1 million and the Vinayagar idol to the [[Toledo Museum of Art]], Ohio and the Uma Maheswari idol to [[Asian Civilisation Museum]], Singapore. The scandal was exposed by the investigative website Chasing Aphrodite, and received wide coverage in the Indian media. The Australian Government decided to return to idol to India and it was handed over to the Indian Prime Minister. The other museums also agreed to return the stolen idols. |<ref name=Mariappan>{{cite news|last1=Mariappan |first1=Julie |title=Stolen Nataraja, Ardhanariswara idols return to the land of temples |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Stolen-Nataraja-Ardhanariswara-idols-return-to-the-land-of-temples/articleshow/42282580.cms |accessdate=September 29, 2015 |issue=Chennai |publisher=The Times of India |date=September 11, 2014 |deadurl=no |archivedate=November 27, 2014}}</ref><ref name=4corners>{{cite news|last1=McDermott |first1=Quentin |last2=Richards |first2=Deborah |title=The Dancing Shiva |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019024217/http://www.abc.net.au/4corners/stories/2014/03/24/3968642.htm |archivedate=October 19, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Morgan>{{cite news|last1=Morgan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929232423/http://chasingaphrodite.com/tag/shiva-nataraja/ |archivedate=September 29, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Toledo-Vinaygar">{{cite web |title=Toledo Museum of Art to Return Ganesha Sculpture to India |url=http://www.toledomuseum.org/2014/10/03/toledo-museum-of-art-to-return-ganesha-sculpture-to-india/ |website=Toledo Museum of Art |accessdate=September 30, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001020558/http://www.toledomuseum.org/2014/10/03/toledo-museum-of-art-to-return-ganesha-sculpture-to-india/ |archivedate=October 1, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="Toledo-Kapoor">{{cite web|title=Kapoor Acquisitions |url=http://www.toledomuseum.org/provenance/kapoor-acquisitions/ |website=Toledo Museum of Art |accessdate=September 30, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929163758/http://www.toledomuseum.org/provenance/kapoor-acquisitions/ |archivedate=September 29, 2015 }}</ref><ref name=Chronicle>{{cite news|title=Stolen idol of Goddess Uma Maheswari to return from Singapore |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/150615/nation-current-affairs/article/stolen-idol-return-singapore |accessdate=September 29, 2015 |issue=Chennai |publisher=Deccan Chronicle |date=June 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019024217/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/150615/nation-current-affairs/article/stolen-idol-return-singapore |archivedate=October 19, 2015}}</ref>
|- |[[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]] art in [[Madrid]] |June 2015, made public in March 2016 |Five paintings –said to be of medium-to-small size and worth a combined estimated €30m– by British artist [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]] were stolen from the Madrid home of their owner during his absence in what has been defined as the largest contemporary art heist in recent Spanish history. The owner is the last known love interest of the painter, from whom he had inheritted the paintings. The art thieves left no fingerprints and managed to get away with the works without setting off any alarms or raising any eyebrows in one of the city’s safest and most heavily monitored districts. In May 2016 seven people were detained in connection with the case, they stand accused for masterminding the heist and are currently on parole. However the artworks (which are believed to remain somewhere in Spain) were not found.
In July 2017 three of the five paintings were recovered by the Spanish police.
|<ref>[http://elpais.com/elpais/2016/03/14/inenglish/1457950007_801886.html Art theft: Art thieves steal five Francis Bacon paintings from Madrid mansion|El Pais] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317210751/http://elpais.com/elpais/2016/03/14/inenglish/1457950007_801886.html |date=March 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.es/cultura/arte/abci-roban-cinco-obras-francis-bacon-casa-amante-espanol-madrid-201603132149_noticia.html |title=Roban cinco obras de Francis Bacon en la casa de su amante
